MINOCYCLINE

TETRACYCLINES

  • Indications and doses
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Less suitable for prescribing
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Susceptible infections (e.g. chlamydia, rickettsia and mycoplasma),

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg twice daily.

Acne vulgaris,

By mouth using modified-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg once daily, alternatively (by mouth) 50 mg twice daily.
  • For adults
    100 mg daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg once daily, alternatively (by mouth) 50 mg twice daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg daily.

Prophylaxis of asymptomatic meningococcal carrier state (but no longer recommended),

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily for 5 days, minocycline treatment is usually followed by administration of rifampicin.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use with caution (avoid excessive doses).

Known side effects

General side effects

rare: Acute renal failure, alopecia, anorexia, hyperaesthesia, impaired hearing, paraesthesia, pigmentation (sometimes irreversible), tinnitus,

veryRare: Discoloration of conjunctiva, discoloration of sweat, discoloration of tears, systemic lupus erythematosus,

notKnown: Dizziness (more common in women), vertigo (more common in women),

Directions for administration

Tablets or capsules should be swallowed whole with plenty of fluid while sitting or standing.

Advice for patients and carers

Counselling on administration advised (posture).

Cautions regarding administration

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

If treatment continued for longer than 6 months, monitor every 3 months for hepatotoxicity, pigmentation and for systemic lupus erythematosus—discontinue if these develop or if pre-existing systemic lupus erythematosus worsens.

Conditions when less suitable for prescribing

Less suitable for prescribing (compared to other tetracyclines, minocycline is associated with a greater risk of lupus-erythematosus-like syndrome; it sometimes causes irreversible pigmentation).

Prepared medicinal forms of MINOCYCLINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, oral solution,
Tablet
Capsule
Modified-release capsule
Dental gel
